Description:
Description of IPC Section 140
According to section 140 of Indian penal code, Whoever, not being a soldier, sailor or airman in the Military, Naval or Air service of the Government of India, wears any garb or carries any token resembling any garb or token used by such a soldier, sailor or airman with the intention that it may be believed that he is such a soldier, sailor or airman, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both.


IPC 140 in Simple Words
If someone who is not a military member wears a uniform or carries something resembling a military uniform to deceive others into believing they are a soldier, sailor, or airman, they can be punished with up to three months in jail, a fine of up to five hundred rupees, or both.
Offense: Wearing the dress or carrying any token used by a soldier, sailor or airman with intent that it may be believed that he is such a soldier, sailor or airman
Actual Punishment:
Punishment - Imprisonment (up to Three Months), Fine (upto Five Hundred Rupee) and Both.

Example:
A person wearing army cap was caught while passing through an airport security check point. The officer asked him about his identity card but when he did not have one on hand, the man lied saying he had lost it at home. He then wore the same hat as if he were serving in the Army. When questioned further regarding this act, the accused said that he would like to serve in the armed forces someday so decided to wear the hat to show off his patriotism.
Predicted Punishment:
Punishment should include the type and duration (if applicable) as well as other relevant information like fines imposed etc.

Explanation:
Section 141 - Offences relating to wearing uniforms or badges on certain occasions; false representation about rank

Description:
Description of IPC Section 127
According to section 127 of Indian penal code, Whoever receives any property knowing the same to have been taken in the commission of any of the offences mentioned in sections 125 and 126, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine and to forfeiture of the property so received.


IPC 127 in Simple Words
If someone receives property knowing it was taken during the commission of certain offenses (mentioned in sections 125 and 126), they can be punished with imprisonment of up to seven years, fined, and the property can be forfeited.
Offense: Receiving property taken by war or depredation mentioned in sections 125 And 126
Actual Punishment:
If anyone takes away another person's belongings while committing an offense under Sections 124A/129B/A, B & C respectively; he/she is punishable with imprisonment upto three years alongwith fine and/or confiscating the stolen goods.

Explanation:
Section 128 provides that whoever commits theft from a dwelling house or other building belonging to some one else, if such offence has been committed after having entered into such place through force or intimidation, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for two years but not less than five years nor more than ten years, and shall also be liable to fine:

1) In case where the offender does not commit the act within twenty-four hours of entering upon the premises;
2) Where there are several offenders;

3) When the amount exceeds Rs.1000/-.

The above provision applies even when the accused enters the residence without permission or consent of its owner.

In addition to this penalty provided under Sec 130(5)(b), every person who knowingly aids or abets the commission of robbery on board ship at sea or harbour, whether as principal or accessory, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or both:


• Provided that no such person shall be convicted unless the court is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that his conduct amounted to aiding or abetting the crime
Predicted Punishment:
If anyone takes your money while committing an offense such as theft or robbery under Sections 379/380/392/394/406/411/409/420/431 etc., then he/she will get imprisoned for at least one year but not more than five years along with fines and confiscating his/her properties.

Explanation:
• The offence is committed if you receive anything from those who are guilty of taking away something else through violence or fraud without their consent.
• For example, when police officers take some goods belonging to people on false grounds, this crime comes into play here because these things were stolen by them using force or deceitful means.
• In addition, there could be other cases where individuals commit crimes against others' possessions like stealing cars, houses, jewelry, gold coins, bank notes, cash deposits, shares & bonds, documents, books, computers, mobile phones, laptops, tablets, cameras, watches, electronic gadgets, precious stones, diamonds, pearls, emeralds, rubies, sapphires, corals, jadeite, lapis lazuli, ambergris, ivory, tortoise shell, whalebone, ostrich feathers, fur coats, leather shoes, boots, gloves, belts, handbags, wallets, purses, scarves, ties, socks, hats, caps, sunglasses, glasses, eyeglasses, spectacles, contact lenses,

Description:
Description of IPC Section 128
According to section 128 of Indian penal code, Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any State prisoner or prisoner of war, voluntarily allows such prisoner to escape from any place in which such prisoner is confined, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 128 in Simple Words
If a public servant, responsible for the custody of a State prisoner or prisoner of war, intentionally allows the prisoner to escape from confinement, they can be punished with life imprisonment or imprisonment of up to ten years, and may also be fined.
Offense: Public servant voluntarily allowing prisoner of State or war in his custody to escape
Actual Punishment:
If a person commits an offence under this chapter, he/she will face one of these punishments:
Life Imprisonment - The offender must serve at least two-thirds (2/3) of their total sentences before becoming eligible for parole.
Imprisonment for Life- This means that you cannot get out until your death.
Imprisonment For Ten Years – You have been sentenced by a court to spend between five and twenty-five years behind bars if convicted on charges related to this offense.

## What does it mean?

The law states that anyone who has control over prisoners should not allow them to leave prison without permission. They are punishable by jail time ranging anywhere from three months to fifteen years depending upon how many times someone escapes while serving their sentence as well as other factors like whether there were multiple attempts made during those periods where no attempt was successful due to security measures taken into account when planning each individual’s release date etcetera!
Predicted Punishment:
A person who commits this offense will face imprisonment for life (Section 129) or imprisonment not exceeding five years (Sections 130-132). The maximum penalty under these sections are as follows:
• If you commit an offence against Sections 131 & 133, then your punishment could range between three months' imprisonment and two years'
• For committing offences that fall within Section 134 - 137, you would receive a prison sentence ranging from six months to seven years.'
The Punishment Under This Act Is Not Less Than Seven Years And Also Cannot Be Lesser In Any Particular Case.'

Description:
Description of IPC Section 129
According to section 129 of Indian penal code, Whoever, being a public servant and having the custody of any State prisoner or prisoner of war, negligently suffers such prisoner to escape from any place of confinement in which such prisoner is confined, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 129 in Simple Words
If a public servant, responsible for the custody of a State prisoner or prisoner of war, carelessly allows the prisoner to escape from confinement, they can be punished with up to three years in jail and may also be fined.
Offense: Public servant negligently suffering prisoner of State or war in his custody to escape
Actual Punishment:
If a person commits an offence under this Act, he/she will have to pay a penalty that ranges between Rs.5000/-to-10 lakh rupees depending on their crime severity.

Explanation:
The word “negligent” means not taking reasonable steps to prevent loss or damage by accident; careless conduct resulting in injury or death (injury) without negligence as defined above;
“Prisoner”, includes every one who has been sentenced to undergo imprisonment either at hard labour or otherwise but does not include-
(a)a convict,
(b)suspect arrested before conviction,

(c)duly convicted offender

(d)any other class of persons specified in clause(1A)

(e)fugitive from justice


Section 130 - Punishment where prisoner escapes while undergoing trial
Predicted Punishment:
A person who commits an offense under this section will have their liberty restricted by law.

Section 130 Offence Against Prisoners (Indian Penal Code)
The following are offences against prisoners:
(1) Any one who abets another to commit offence punishable under sections 124-A, 125-B, 126A or 127B.
Explanation.—For the purposes of this sub-section,—

(a) "abet" means to advise; and


(b) "officer-in-charge" includes—
(i) The officer on duty at the time when the act was committed,
(ii) An assistant officer not below the rank of constable, if he has been specially appointed as an escorting officer for that purpose,

and every other person acting in accordance with instructions issued by him;
(2) Anyone who aids, abets, counsels, procures or induces any person to do anything done by him contrary to the provisions of sections 124-A, 125-B, 126A or 127 B.

Explain what does it mean?
This explains how someone else could help you get out of prison without your consent even though you were imprisoned because of them. This applies to anyone who helps others break laws related to prisons. It doesn't matter whether they did so intentionally or unintentionally - both types of people would still face criminal charges.

What happens after conviction? Explain briefly!
After

Description:
Description of IPC Section 130
According to section 130 of Indian penal code, Whoever knowingly aids or assists any State prisoner or prisoner of war in escaping from lawful custody, or rescues or attempts to rescue any such prisoner, or harbours or conceals any such prisoner who has escaped from lawful custody, or offers or attempts to offer any resistance to the recapture of such prisoner shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 130 in Simple Words
If someone knowingly helps a State prisoner or prisoner of war escape from lawful custody, rescues them, hides them after their escape, or resists their recapture, they can be punished with life imprisonment or imprisonment of up to ten years, and may also be fined.
Offense: Aiding escape of, rescuing or harbouring, such prisoner, or offering Any resistance to the recapture of such prisoner
Actual Punishment:
If anyone knows that he is helping another person by providing him food or shelter then it will amount as an offence under this law.

Explanation:
This offense comes within the definition given above i.e., whoever knowingly aids or assists any state prisoner or prisoner of war in escaping from lawful custody; or rescues or attempts to rescue any such prisoner, or harbors or conceals any such prisoner who has escaped from lawful custody; or offers or attempts to offer any resistance to the recapture of such prisoner shall be punishable with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
Predicted Punishment:
If anyone knows that he is aiding an escapee then it becomes his duty to inform the police immediately as soon as possible so that law enforcement officials could take necessary steps against him.

Explanation:
Section 131 states that whoever commits offence under sections 129 & 132 will get same punishment like those offences committed by other persons but if offender tries to commit another crime during this period than he gets additional penalty according to severity of previous crimes.

Description:
Description of IPC Section 131
According to section 131 of Indian penal code, Whoever abets the committing of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India or attempts to seduce any such officer, soldier, sailor or airman from his allegiance or his duty, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 131 in Simple Words
If someone encourages the commission of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman in the Indian Army, Navy, or Air Force or tries to lead them astray from their loyalty or duty, they can be punished with life imprisonment or imprisonment of up to ten years, and may also be fined.
Offense: Abetting mutiny, or attempting to seduce an officer, soldier sailor or airman from his allegiance or duty
Actual Punishment:
Punishment is Life Imprisonment/Imprisonment Of Either Descript For A Term Which May Extend To Ten Years And Shall Also Be Liable To Fine.

Explanation:
Section 132 provides that whoever commits offence under sections 130 (abetting mutiny) &133 (attempting to commit mutiny), he will get death penalty if convicted on first conviction; while second time it would amount to rigorous imprisonment for seven year’s period but no more than twenty five years’ period. If convict gets third offense then it becomes non-cognizable case as per Sec-228(1).
Predicted Punishment: Punishment is given as Life Imprisonment/Imprisonment For A Term Which May Extend To Ten Years And Fine

Description:
Description of IPC Section 132
According to section 132 of Indian penal code, Whoever abets the committing of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, shall, if mutiny be committed in consequence of that abetment, be punished with death or with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 132 in Simple Words
If someone encourages the commission of mutiny by an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman in the Indian Army, Navy, or Air Force, and mutiny occurs as a result, the abettor can be punished with death, life imprisonment, or imprisonment for up to ten years, and may also be fined.
Offense: Abetment of mutiny, if mutiny is committed in consequence thereof
Actual Punishment:
If anyone commits mutiny against his superior authority (i.e., army commander) because he was encouraged to do so through some kind of abuse, bribery, etc., then such person will get punished under this law.

Explanation:
Abetting means encouraging another individual to commit any crime; therefore, it implies that one has intentionally aided the other's actions without actually performing them oneself.
In simple words, we could say that "abuse" refers to using force on others while "encouraging" involves persuading people not to follow certain rules set forth by their leaders.
Predicted Punishment:
If anyone incites others to commit mutiny against their superior officers, they will face severe punishments under this provision.

Explanation:
The word 'abate' means "to stop" or "prevent." The act of encouraging another person's misconduct (such as insubordination) is known as "abetting."
In order to avoid ambiguity, we must distinguish between two different meanings of the phrase “in consequence.” In other words, it doesn't matter whether one acts on behalf of another individual who has already been convicted; rather than punishing them directly, he punishes those individuals indirectly through his actions.
This law applies not just to military personnel but also civilian employees working at government institutions such as airports, ports, railways, etc., whose duties include guarding national security secrets from being disclosed publicly.

Description:
Description of IPC Section 133
According to section 133 of Indian penal code, Whoever abets an assault by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, on any superior officer being in the execution of his office, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 133 in Simple Words
If someone encourages an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman to assault a superior officer while the superior officer is performing their duties, the abettor can be punished with up to three years in jail and a fine.
Offense: Abetment of an assault by An officer, soldier, sailor Or airman on his superior officer, when in the execution of his office
Actual Punishment:
Punishment under this section includes:
Imprisonment For A Term Which May Extend To Three Years And Fine
Predicted Punishment: Punishment - Imprisonment for upto Three Years & Fine

Description:
Description of IPC Section 134
According to section 134 of Indian penal code, Whoever abets an assault by an officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, on any superior officer being in the execution of his office, shall, if such assault be committed in consequence of that abetment be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.


IPC 134 in Simple Words
If someone encourages an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman to assault a superior officer while the superior officer is performing their duties, and the assault occurs as a result, the abettor can be punished with up to seven years in jail and a fine.
Offense: Abetment of such assault, if the assault is committed
Actual Punishment:
If anyone provides encouragement (abatement) to another person's crime against a police official then he/she will get five-year imprisonment along with Rs.1 lakh penalty.

Explanation:
Abetting means encouraging; assisting somebody else to commit a wrong act.
In this case, it was not necessary to prove that the accused actually encouraged the offence but merely proved that they provided some kind of assistance towards committing the offence.
The word "assistance" includes all kinds of help given from one individual to another without demanding anything in return.
For example - A gives money to B so that B goes out to rob C who happens to pass near them at night time.
Here both A & B are providing each other's support even though there is no direct connection between them i.e., neither A nor B demanded something from others like money etc.,
Therefore, here we have two offences under sections 120B & 302 IPC respectively,
and therefore, according to our law, whoever abates these offenses should face severe punishments

FAQs On IPC 134
Predicted Punishment: If anyone provides assistance to another person who commits an offence against public order (such as rioting) they will face a maximum penalty of two years' imprisonment plus a minimum fine of Rs.10,000/-.

Description:
Description of IPC Section 135
According to section 135 of Indian penal code, Whoever, abets the desertion of any officer, soldier, sailor or airman, in the Army, Navy or Air Force of the Government of India, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.


IPC 135 in Simple Words
If someone encourages or supports the desertion of an officer, soldier, sailor, or airman from the Indian Army, Navy, or Air Force, they can be punished with up to two years in jail, a fine, or both.
Offense: Abetment of the desertion of an officer, soldier, sailor or airman
Actual Punishment:
Punishment is given as per law and it depends on severity of offense committed by person.

Example:
Abetting Desertion

In this case, if anyone encourage another person to leave his job then he will face severe punishments according to law.

Explanation:

The offence under sections 134 & 136 are punishable with imprisonment upto one year (or) fine/both.

Section 133 deals with attempt to commit offences against State Govt., while Sections 137-140 deal with conspiracy etc.

• Attempt means doing something that would lead to commission of crime but not actually committing the act itself; Conspiracy refers to agreement between persons who have no intention of carrying out their own part of plan together.

For example:- A man tries to kill his wife using poison. He has attempted murder. But due to lack of money, he could not carry through the plan. In such cases also, he faces charges of attempting murder.

But there's more than just these three offenses - some crimes require multiple elements before you're found guilty of them all at once! For instance...
Predicted Punishment: Punishment is given by law as per IPC Chapter-129
